member.name: T:MccDaq.CountingMode
member.summary: Specifies the valid operating modes for a C7266 counter.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CountingMode.NormalMode
member.summary: The operating mode is normal.
member.remarks: Each counter operates as a 24-bit counter that rolls over to 0 when the maximum count is reached.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CountingMode.RangeLimit
member.summary: The operating mode is range limit.
member.remarks: An upper and lower limit is set that mimicks limit switches in the mechanical counterpart. The upper limit is set by loading the PRESET register with the CLoad method after the counter is configured. The lower limit is always 0. When counting up, the counter freezes when the count reaches the value loaded into the PRESET register. When counting down, the counter freezes at 0. In either case, the counting only resumes when the count direction is reversed.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CountingMode.NoRecycle
member.summary: The operating mode is non-recycle.
member.remarks: The counter is disabled when a count overflow or underflow occurs. The counter is re-enabled when a reset or load operation is performed on the counter.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CountingMode.ModuloN
member.summary: The operating mode is ModuloN.
member.remarks: The upper limit is set by loading the PRESET register with a maximum count. When the maximum count is reached when counting up, the counter rolls over to 0 and continues counting up. When the count reaches 0 when counting down, the counter rolls over to the maximum count (in the PRESET register) and continues counting down.

member.name: T:MccDaq.DataEncoding
member.summary: Specifies the format of data returned by a 7266 counter.

member.name: F:MccDaq.DataEncoding.BcdEncoding
member.summary: The data is returned using BCD encoding.

member.name: F:MccDaq.DataEncoding.BinaryEncoding
member.summary: The data is returned using binary encoding.

member.name: T:MccDaq.IndexMode
member.summary: Specifies the action to take when the Index signal is received by a 7266 counter.
member.remarks: The IndexMode must be set to IndexDisabled whenever a Quadrature is set to NOQuad, or when GateState is set to Enabled.

member.name: F:MccDaq.IndexMode.IndexDisabled
member.summary: The Index signal is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.IndexMode.LoadCtr
member.summary: The counter is loaded whenever the index signal on the LCNTR pin occurs.

member.name: F:MccDaq.IndexMode.LoadOutLatch
member.summary: The current count is latched whenever the Index signal on the LCNTR pin occurs.
member.remarks: When selected, the method returns the same count each time it is called until the Index signal occurs.

member.name: F:MccDaq.IndexMode.ResetCtr
member.summary: The counter is reset to 0 whenever the Index signal on the RCNTR pin occurs.

member.name: T:MccDaq.FlagPins
member.summary: Specifies which signals will be routed to the FLG1 and FLG2 pins on a 7266 counter.

member.name: F:MccDaq.FlagPins.CarryBorrow
member.summary: The FLG1 pin is the Carry output, and the FLG2 pin is the Borrow output.

member.name: F:MccDaq.FlagPins.CompareBorrow
member.summary: The FLG1 pin is the Compare output, and the FLG2 pin is the Borrow output.

member.name: F:MccDaq.FlagPins.CarryBorrowUpDown
member.summary: The FLG1 pin is the Carry/Borrow output, and the FLG2 pin is the Up/Down signal.

member.name: F:MccDaq.FlagPins.IndexError
member.summary: The FLG1 pin is the Index output, and the FLG2 pin is the Error output.

member.name: T:MccDaq.StatusBits
member.summary: Specifies all status bits that are available when reading a counter status.
member.remarks: Status bits can be combined using a bitwise OR operation.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.UnderFlow
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 whenever the count decrements past 0, and cleared to 0 whenever method is called.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.OverFlow
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 whenever the count increments past it's upper limit, and cleared to 0 whenever method is called.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.Compare
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 whenever the count matches the preset register, and cleared to 0 whenever method is called.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.Sign
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 when the MSB of the count is 1, and is cleared to 0 whenever the MSB of the count is set to 0.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.Error
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 whenever an error occurs due to excessive noise on the input, and is cleared to 0 by calling method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.Updown
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 when counting up, and cleared to 0 when counting down.

member.name: F:MccDaq.StatusBits.Index
member.summary: This bit is set to 1 when index is valid, and is cleared to 0 when index is not valid.

member.name: T:MccDaq.TriggerType
member.summary: Specifies all valid trigger types for the method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigAbove
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external analog trigger makes a transition from below highThreshold to above. Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigBelow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external analog trigger input makes a transition from above lowThreshold to below. Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateNegHys
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external analog trigger input is more positive than highThreshold. AD conversions are disabled when the external analog trigger input more negative than Low/Threshold.
member.remarks: Hysteresis is the level between Low/Threshold and highThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GatePosHys
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external analog trigger input is more negative than lowThreshold. AD conversions are disabled when the external analog trigger input is more positive than highThreshold.
member.remarks: Hysteresis is the level between lowThreshold and highThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateAbove
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external analog trigger input is more positive than highThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateBelow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external analog trigger input is more negative than lowThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateInWindow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external analog trigger is inside the region defined by lowThreshold and highThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateOutWindow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external analog trigger is outside the region defined by lowThreshold and highThreshold.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateHigh
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external digital trigger input is 5 V (logic HIGH or 1).

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.GateLow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled as long as the external digital trigger input is 0 V (logic LOW or 0).

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigHigh
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external digital trigger is 5V (logic HIGH or '1'). Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigLow
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external digital trigger is 0V (logic LOW or '0'). Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigPosEdge
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external digital trigger makes a transition from 5 V to 0 V (logic HIGH to LOW). Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: F:MccDaq.TriggerType.TrigNegEdge
member.summary: AD conversions are enabled when the external digital trigger makes a transition from 0 V to 5 V (logic LOW to HIGH). Once conversions are enabled, the external trigger is ignored.

member.name: T:MccDaq.SoftwareTriggerType
member.summary: Specifies all valid trigger types for software triggering.

member.name: F:MccDaq.SoftwareTriggerType.TrigAbove
member.summary: Software triggering is TrigAbove.

member.name: F:MccDaq.SoftwareTriggerType.TrigBelow
member.summary: Software triggering is TrigBelow.

member.name: T:MccDaq.ConnectionPin
member.summary: Specifies the pin to associate with the signal type and direction of timing and control signals when calling the method.

item.description: Each active DAQ-Sync connector pins is dedicated (hardwired) to a particular signal type. Therefore, when a DAQ-Sync connector is indicated as a connection (), the exact physical connection pin on the DAQ-Sync connector is dictated by the selected signal rather than the connection code itself.
The AuxIn and AuxOut settings match their corresponding hardware pin names.

Multiple input signals can be mapped to the same AuxIn connection by successive calls to the method.
For example, and can share the same physical input signal received by a specific connection, such as AuxIn0. However, only one connection can be mapped to each input signal. If another connection is assigned to an input signal, the first selection is de-assigned.
For example, the AdcConvert signal cannot simultaneously receive physical input from multiple connections (such as AuxIn0 and AuxIn3). If AdcConvert is initially set to receive the input from AuxIn0, and through another method call, AdcConvert is mapped to AuxIn3, and the first AdcConvert no longer receives the physical input from the AuxIn0 connection. AuxIn3 becomes the new physical input for the AdcConvert signal.

Only one output signal can be mapped to the same AuxOut connection. If an output signal is already assigned to a connection, when another output signal is mapped to the same connection, the first output signal is de-assigned and the new output signal is assigned to the connection.
For example, the AdcConvert and AdcStartTrig signals cannot be output simultaneously through the same physical connection, such as AuxOut0. If AdcConvert initially outputs its signal to AuxOut0, and through another method call, AdcStartTrig is set to output its signal to the same AuxOut0, the first AdcConvert not longer outputs from AuxOut0, and AuxOut0 instead outputs the AdcStartTrig signal.
However, multiple connections can be mapped to the same output connection by successive calls to .
For example, AdcConvert can output its physical signal simultaneously from AuxOut0 and AuxOut1.
When selecting DsConnector for a signal, only one Direction per signal type can be defined at a given time.

member.name: T:MccDaq.EventType
member.summary: Specifies all available event conditions that can be bound to the user-callback function.
member.remarks: More than one event type can be specified by bitwise OR'ing the event types.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnScanError
member.summary: Generates an event when a driver error is detected during input and output scans.
member.remarks: The detected error can include , , and errors.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnExternalInterrupt
member.summary: Generates an event when a pulse is detected at the External Interrupt pin (applies to some digital and counter boards only).

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnPretrigger
member.summary: Generates an event when the first trigger is detected ( method).

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnDataAvailable
member.summary: Generates an event when the number of samples acquired during an analog input scan increases by EventParameter samples or more.

remarks.para: Events are generated on packet transfers for BlockIo scans.
For method, the first event is not generated until a minimum of EventParam samples after the pretrigger.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnEndOfAiScan
member.summary: Generates an event upon completion or fatal error of method or method.
member.remarks: This event is NOT generated when scans are aborted using method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnEndOfAoScan
member.summary: Generates an event upon completion or fatal error of method.
member.remarks: This event is NOT generated when scans are aborted using method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.OnChangeOfDigInput
member.summary: Not implemented.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventType.AllEventTypes
member.summary: Disables all events.

member.name: T:MccDaq.EventParameter
member.summary: Specifies the options for latching data on supported Measurement Computing hardware.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventParameter.Default
member.summary: The latching mode is automatically applied based on the board type.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventParameter.LatchDI
member.summary: Returns data that was latchched in at the most recent interrupt edge. The current value of the digital inputs is read and stored (0 or 1). The stored value is updated when an active edge occurs.

member.name: F:MccDaq.EventParameter.LatchDO
member.summary: Latches out data most recently written to the device. The digital outputs are not set to the value written until an active edge occurs.

member.name: T:MccDaq.ScanOptions
member.summary: Specifies the available options for paced input/output functions.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.Default
member.summary: The optimum sampling mode is automatically applied based on board type and sampling speed.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.Background
member.summary: Data collection into the buffer continues in the background; program control returns immediately to the next line in the program.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.Continuous
member.summary: Puts the method in an endless loop.

remarks.para: Once this option outputs the specified number (numPoints) of D/A values, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with method. Normally this option should be used in combination with Background so that your program will regain control.
This option may only be used with boards which support interrupt, DMA or REP-INSW transfer methods.
Refer to the board-specific information in the Universal Library User's Guide for packet size information for your particular DAQ hardware.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ExtClock
member.summary: Conversions are controlled by the signal on the external clock input rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal. The rate parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal. Options for the device default to a transfer mode that allows the maximum conversion rate to be attained unless otherwise specified.
member.remarks: SingleIo is recommended for slow external clock rates. If the rate of the external clock is very slow (less than 200 Hz) and the board you are using supports BlockIo, include the SingleIo option.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ConvertData
member.summary: For 12 bit boards, data returned to the buffer is automatically converted to 12 bit A/D values. If ConvertData is not used, data is returned unmodified (16-bit values that contain both a 12-bit A/D value and a 4-bit channel number). After the data collection is complete call method to convert the data after the fact. Do not specify this option if you are using the Background option and DMA transfers.
member.remarks: This option is ignored for 16-bit boards.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.DtConnect
member.summary: All A/D values are sent to the A/D board's DT-Connect port.
member.remarks: This option is incorporated into the ExtMemory option. Use this option only if the external board is not supported by Universal Library.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ScaleData
member.summary: Data is scaled to engineering units and stored in the scan buffer.
member.remarks: This option forces the conversion of raw data to engineering units durng the scan. While this removes the post-acquisition processing of data to engineering units, the original, uncoverted data cannot be recovered. Note that WinBufAlloc64 should used for buffer allocation and ScaledWinBufArray32 should be used for retrieving data from the buffer.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.SingleIo
member.summary: A/D conversions and transfers to memory are initiated by an interrupt. One interrupt per conversion.
member.remarks: Rates attainable using SINGLEIO are PC-dependent and generally less than 10 kHz. Use the default method unless you have a reason to select a specific transfer method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.DmaIo
member.summary: A/D conversions are initiated by a trigger. Transfers are initiated by a DMA request.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.BlockIo
member.summary: A/D conversions are initiated by a trigger. Transfers are handled in blocks (by REP-INSW for example).
member.remarks: BlockIo is not recommended for slow acquisition rates, such as less than 200 Hz.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.BurstIo
member.summary: Allows higher sampling rates for sample counts up to full FIFO. Data is collected into the local FIFO. Data transfers to the PC are held off until after the scan is complete.
member.remarks: For Background scans, the count and index returned by method remain 0 and the status equals "Running" until the scan finishes. When the scan is complete and the data is retrieved, the count and index are updated and the status equals "Idle". BurstIo is the default mode for non-Continuous fast scans (aggregate sample rates above 1000 Hz) with sample counts up to full-FIFO. To avoid the BurstIo default, specify BlockIo.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.WordXfer
member.summary: Read or write two adjacent ports as the low and high byte of a single array element from/to the buffer.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.Simultaneous
member.summary: Updates all D/A voltages simultaneously when the last D/A in the scan is updated.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.NoFilter
member.summary: No smoothing function is applied to temperature readings, resulting in a scattering of readings around a mean.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ExtMemory
member.summary: Data is sent to a connected memory board via the DT-Connect interface rather than returning the data to the buffer.
member.remarks: Data is appended unless is called. The data should be unloaded with the method before collecting new data. When ExtMemory option is used, the reference to the buffer (memHandle) may be set to null or 0. The Continuous option cannot be used with ExtMemory. Do not use ExtMemory and together. Transfer modes , , and have no meaning when used with this option.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.BurstMode
member.summary: Enables burst mode sampling. Scans from lowChan to highChan are clocked at the maximum A/D rate between samples in order to minimize channel to channel skew. Scans are initiated at the rate specified by rate.
member.remarks: BurstMode is not recommended for use with the SingleIo option. If this combination is used, set the count value as low as possible, preferably to the number of channels in the scan, or overruns may occur.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.NoTodInts
member.summary: Disables the system's time-of-day interrupts for the duration of the scan.
member.remarks: Time-of-day interrupts are used to update the systems real time clock, and can limit the maximum sampling speed of some boards. If the interrupts are turned off using this option, the real time clock will fall behind by the length of time that the scan takes.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ExtTrigger
member.summary: Sampling begins when a trigger condition is met.
member.remarks: This trigger condition is programmable on many boards. On other boards, only 'polled gate' triggering is supported. Assuming active high operation, data acquisition commences immediately if the clock input is high. If the clock input is low, acquisition will be held off unit until it goes high. Acquisition will continue until numPoints samples have been taken regardless of the state of the clock input. This option is most useful if the signal is a pulse with a very low duty cycle (trigger signal in TTL low state most of the time) so that triggering will be held off until the occurrence of the pulse.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.NoCalibrateData
member.summary: Turns off real-time software calibration for boards which are software calibrated. this is done by applying calibration factors to the data on a sample by sample basis as it is acquired.
member.remarks: Turning off software calibration saves CPU time during a high speed acquisition run. For example, this may be required if your processor is less than a 150 megahertz (MHz) Pentium and you want an acquisition speed greater than 200 kHz. DO NOT use this option if you do not have to. If this option is used, calibrate the data after the acquisition run with the method.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.RetrigMode
member.summary: Enables the retrigger mode in which the hardware trigger is re-armed without having to start a new scan.
member.remarks: If the A/D retrigger count is set to a value less than the scan total count, the scan will wait for the next trigger after acquiring the retrigger count samples.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.NonStreamedIO
member.summary: Enables generation of non-streamed data output.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ADCClockTrig
member.summary: Data output is triggered upon the start of the ADC clock.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ScanOptions.ADCClock
member.summary: Data output is paced by the ADC clock.

member.name: T:MccDaq.ThermocoupleOptions
member.summary: Specifies whether or not to apply a smoothing function to temperature readings.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ThermocoupleOptions.Filter
member.summary: A smoothing function is applied to temperature readings.
member.remarks: Ten samples are read from the specified channel and averaged. The average is the reading returned. Averaging removes normally distributed signal line noise.

member.name: F:MccDaq.ThermocoupleOptions.NoFilter
member.summary: No smoothing function is applied to temperature readings, resulting in a scattering of readings around a mean.

member.summary: Specifies the file type used to convert a binary log file.

member.name: T:MccDaq.CounterDebounceMode
member.summary: Specifies the options for setting the debounce mode.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CounterDebounceMode.TriggerAfterStable
member.summary: Rejects glitches, and only passes state transitions after a specified period of stability (the debounce time).
member.remarks: This mode is used with electro-mechanical devices like encoders and mechanical switches to reject switch bounce and disturbances due to a vibrating encoder that is not otherwise moving. Set the debounce time to be short enough to accept the desired input pulse, but longer than the period of the undesired disturbance.

member.name: F:MccDaq.CounterDebounceMode.TriggerBeforeStable
member.summary: Use when the input signal has groups of glitches, and each group is to be counted as one.
member.remarks: This mode recognizes and counts the first glitch within a group, but rejects subsequent glitches within the group if the debounce time is set accordingly. Set the debounce time to encompass one entire group of glitches.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.ACalibrateData(System.Int32,MccDaq.Range,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Calibrates the raw data collected by method from devices with real-time software calibration when the real-time calibration has been turned off. The AInScan method returns either raw A/D data or calibrated data, depending on whether or not the option was used.
member.param: The number of samples to calibrate.
The programmable gain/range used when the data was collected.
Upon return, contains the calibrated data.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks:
When collecting data using method with the NoCalibrateData option, use this method to calibrate the data after it is collected.
The name of array must match that used in AInScan.
Applying software calibration factors in real-time on a per-sample basis eats up machine cycles. If your CPU is slow, or if processing time is at a premium, withhold calibration until after the acquisition run is complete. Turning off real-time software calibration saves CPU time during a high-speed acquisition run.
Processor speed is a factor for DMA transfers and for real-time software calibration. Processors of less than 150 megahertz (MHz) Pentium class may impose speed limits below the capability of the Measurement Computing device (refer to your Measurement Computing device manual or the Universal Library User's Guide). If your processor is less than a 150 MHz Pentium, and you need an acquisition speed in excess of 200 kilohertz (kHz), use the NoCalibrateData option to a turn off real-time software calibration and save CPU time. After the acquisition is run, calibrate the data with ACalibrateData.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.AConvertData(System.Int32,System.Int16@,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Converts the raw data collected by method into 12-bit A/D values. The AInScan method returns either raw A/D data or converted data, depending on whether or not the option is used. For many 12-bit A/D boards, the raw data is a 16-bit value that contains a 12-bit A/D value and a 4-bit channel tag (refer to your Measurement Computing device manual or the Universal Library User's Guide). The converted data consists of just the 12-bit A/D value.
member.param: The number of samples to convert.
The pointer to the start of the data array.
Upon return, contains the pointer to the start of the channel tag array (if available).
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks:
When collecting data using method without the ConvertData option, use this method to convert the data after it has been collected. There are cases where the ConvertData option is not allowed. For example, if you are using both the and options with AInScan. In those cases, this method should be used to convert the data after the data collection is complete.
For some boards, each raw data point consists of a 12-bit A/D value with a 4-bit channel number. This method pulls each data point apart and puts the A/D value into the adData array and the channel number into the array.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.AConvertPretrigData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int16@,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Converts the raw data collected by the method.
member.param: The number of pre-trigger samples to convert. This number must match the number returned by the parameter in the method.
The total number of samples to convert.
The pointer to the data array. Array name must match the name of the array used with the method.

Upon return, contains the pointer to the start of the channel tag array (if available). Returns NULL if using a 16-bit board or if channel tags not available. Refer to 16-bit board information in "Remarks" section.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: The method returns either raw A/D data or converted data, depending on whether or not the option was used. The raw data is not in the correct order as it is collected. After the data collection is completed, it must be rearranged into the correct order. This method also orders the data, starting with the first pretrigger data point and ending with the last post-trigger point.

On some 12-bit A/D boards, each raw data point consists of a 12-bit A/D value with a 4-bit channel number. This method pulls each data point apart and puts the A/D value into the and the channel number into the array.
Upon returning from AConvertPretrigData, the array contains only 12-bit A/D data.
Use this method with 16-bit A/D boards only to order the data. No channel tags are returned.

VB .Net programmers: After the data is collected with the method, it must be copied to a BASIC array with the method.
The entire array must be copied, which includes the extra 512 samples needed by the method.

member.summary: Reads an A/D channel from a Measurement Computing A/D device, and returns a 16-bit integer value.
member.param: The number of the A/D channel to read.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Upon return, contains the A/D value read from the channel on the Measurement Computing device.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description:
The maximum allowable number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured.
Expansion boards are also supported by this method, so this parameter can be set to up to 272. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on specific Measurement Computing expansion devices.

If the selected A/D device does not have a programmable gain feature, the parameter is ignored.
If the A/D device does have programmable gain, set the parameter to the desired A/D range. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the supported A/D ranges of each Measurement Computing A/D device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.AInScan(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,MccDaq.Range,System.Int32,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Scans a range of A/D channels on a Measurement Computing A/D device and stores the samples in an array.
member.param: The number of the first A/D channel to scan.
The number of the last A/D channel to scan.
The number of A/D samples to collect.

param.name: rate
param.para: The sample rate—in scans per second per channel— at which the scans are triggered.
Upon return, contains the actual sample rate in scans per second per channel.

member.param: A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Handle for the Windows buffer used to store data. This buffer must have been previously allocated with the method.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: The number of points scanned per channel = /( – + 1)

The maximum allowable / number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured.

description.para: Transfer method options: The following four options determine how data is transferred from the board to PC memory. If none of these options is specified (recommended), the optimum sampling mode will automatically be chosen based on board type and sampling speed.
- A/D transfers to memory are initiated by an interrupt. One interrupt per conversion.
- A/D transfers are initiated by a DMA request.

- A/D transfers are handled in blocks (by REP-INSW for example). BlockIo is not recommended for slow acquisition rates: If the rate of acquisition is very slow (say less than 200 Hz) BlockIo is probably not the best choice for transfer mode. The reason for this is that status for the operation is not available until one packet of data has been collected (typically 512 samples). The implication is that if acquiring 100 samples at 100 Hz using BlockIo, the operation will not complete until 5.12 seconds has elapsed.

- Allows higher sampling rates for sample counts up to full FIFO. Data is collected into the local FIFO. Data transfers to the PC are held off until after the scan is complete. For Background scans, the count and index returned by method remain 0 and the status equals Running until the scan finishes. When the scan is complete and the data is retrieved, the count and index are updated and the status equals Idle . BurstIo is the default mode for non-Continuous fast scans (aggregate sample rates above 1000 Hz) with sample counts up to full-FIFO. To avoid the BurstIo default, specify BlockIo. BurstIo is not a valid option for most boards. It is used mainly for USB products.

item.description:
Other settings
- Enables burst mode sampling. Scans from to are clocked at the maximum A/D rate between samples in order to minimize channel to channel skew. Scans are initiated at the rate specified by rate. BurstMode is not recommended for use with the SingleIo option. If this combination is used, the count value should be set as low as possible, preferably to the number of channels in the scan. Otherwise, overruns may occur.
- If the ConvertData option is used for 12-bit devices, then the data that is returned to the buffer is automatically converted to 12-bit A/D values. If ConvertDatais not used, then the data from 12-bit A/D devices is returned unmodified (16-bit values that contain both a 12-bit A/D value and a 4-bit channel number). After the data collection is complete, you can call method to convert the data after the fact. ConvertData may not be specified if you are using the Background option and DMA transfers. This option is ignored for the 16-bit boards.
- If the Background option is not used, the AInScan method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program and the data collection from the A/D into the buffer continues in the background. Use method to check on the status of the background operation. Alternatively, some boards support method for event notification of changes in status of Background scans. Use method to stop the background process before it has completed. StopBackground should be executed after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it collects the required number of samples, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with method. Normally this option should be used in combination with Background so that your program regains control.
For some Measurement Computing devices, must be an integer multiple of the packet size. Packet size is the amount of data that a Measurement Computing device transmits back to the PC's memory buffer during each data transfer. Packet size can differ among Measurement Computing devices, and can even differ on the same Measurement Computing product depending on the transfer method.
In some cases, the minimum value for the parameter may change when the Continuous option is used. This can occur for several reasons, the most common being that in order to trigger an interrupt on boards with FIFOs, the circular buffer must occupy at least half the FIFO. Typical half-FIFO sizes are 256, 512 and 1024.
Another reason for a minimum value is that the buffer in memory must be periodically transferred to the user buffer. If the buffer is too small, data will be overwritten during the transfer resulting in corrupted data.
Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the packet size for your particular Measurement Computing device.
- If this option is used, then conversions are controlled by the signal on the external clock input rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (see the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing device). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate is dependent on the clock signal. Options for the device default to a transfer mode that allows the maximum conversion rate to be attained unless otherwise specified. If the rate of the external clock is very slow (say less than 200 Hz) and the device you are using supports BlockIo, you may want to include the SingleIo option. This is because that the status for the operation is not available until one packet of data has been collected (typically 512 samples). The implication is that, if acquiring 100 samples at 100 Hz using BlockIo (the default for boards that support it if ExtClock is used), the operation will not complete until 5.12 seconds has elapsed
- Causes the command to send the data to a connected memory device via the DT- Connect interface rather than returning the data to the buffer. Data for each call to this method is appended unless method is called. The data should be unloaded with the method before collecting new data. When the ExtMemory option is used, the reference to the buffer () may be set to null or 0. Continuous option cannot be used with ExtMemory. Do not use ExtMemory and DtConnect together. The transfer modes DmaIo, SingleIo and BlockIo have no meaning when used with this option.
- If this option is specified, the sampling does not begin until the trigger condition is met. On many devices, this trigger condition is programmable (refer to method and the Universal Library User's Guide for information on specific Measurement Computing A/D devices.). On other devices, only "polled gate"' triggering is supported. In this case, assuming active high operation, data acquisition starts immediately if the trigger input is high. If the trigger input is low, acquisition is held off unit until it goes high. Acquisition continues until samples have been taken regardless of the state of the trigger input. This option is most useful if the signal is a pulse with a very low duty cycle (trigger signal in TTL low state most of the time) so that triggering is held off until the pulse occurs.
- If this option is specified, the system's time-of-day interrupts are disabled for the duration of the scan. These interrupts are used to update the systems real-time clock and are also used by various other programs. These interrupts can limit the maximum sampling speed of some devices. If the interrupts are turned off using this option then the real-time clock falls behind by the length of time that the scan takes.
- Turns off real-time software calibration for boards which are software calibrated, by applying calibration factors to the data on a sample by sample basis as it is acquired. Turning off software calibration saves CPU time during a high speed acquisition run. This may be required if your processor is less than a 150 MHz Pentium and you desire an acquisition speed in excess of 200 kHz. These numbers may not apply to your system. Only trial will tell for sure. DO NOT use this option if you do not have to. If this option is used, the data must be calibrated after the acquisition run with the method.
- All A/D values will be sent to the A/D board's DT-Connect port. This option is incorporated into the ExtMemory option. Use DTConnect only if the external device is not supported by Universal Library.

remarks.note:
An error occurs if you specify a total A/D rate beyond the capability of the Measurement Computing device. For example, if you specify = 0, = 4 (five channels total) and = 20,000, and you are using a Measurement Computing device that can convert a maximum of 50,000 samples per second per channel, you will get an error. You have specified a total rate of 5*20,000 = 100,000.
The maximum sampling rate depends on both the A/D device being used and on the sampling mode options. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the sampling rates of your Measurement Computing A/D device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.ALoadQueue(System.Int16[],MccDaq.Range[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the Measurement Computing A/D device's channel/gain queue. This method only works with A/D devices that have channel/gain queue hardware.
member.param: Array containing the channel values to load into the channel gain queue.
Array containing A/D range values to load into the channel gain queue.
Set the number of elements in and to load into the channel/gain queue. A setting of 0 disables the channel/gain queue.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: Some products do not support channel/gain queue, and some that do support it are limited on the order of elements, number of elements, gain values that can be included, and so on. Refer to the device-specific information in the the Universal Library User's Guide for details on your Measurement Computing product.
and should contain at least elements. The number of elements depends on the queue size of the A/D device's channel gain queue.

Normally, the method scans a fixed range of channels (from to ) at a fixed A/D range. If you load the channel gain queue with this method, then all subsequent calls to AInScan cycle through the channel/range pairs that you have loaded into the queue.

member.summary: Outputs values to a range of D/A channels. This method can be used for paced analog output on Measurement Computing devices that support paced output. It can also be used to update all analog outputs at the same time when the option is used.
member.param: The number of the first D/A channel to scan.
The number of the last D/A channel to scan.
The number of D/A samples to output

The sample rate in scans per second.
Upon return, contains the actual sample rate in scans per second per channel.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Handle for the Windows buffer used to to output data. This buffer must first be allocated with the method, and contain the data to be output (perhaps with the method).
bit fields that set various scanning modes.

item.description: The number of points scanned per channel = /( – + 1)

parameter settings
- This option may only be used with Measurement Computing devices that support interrupt, DMA or REP-INSW transfer methods. This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it outputs the specified number () of D/A values, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with the method. This option should only be used in combination with Background so that your program can regain control.
Background - This option may only be used with Measurement Computing devices that support interrupt, DMA or REP-INSW transfer methods. When this option is used, the D/A operations begin running in the background, and control immediately returns to the next line of your program. Use method to check the status of a background operation. Alternatively, some Measurement Computing devices support method for event notification of changes in status of Background scans. Use method to terminate background operations before they are completed. StopBackground should be executed after normal termination of all background methods in order to clear variables and flags.
Simultaneous - When this option is used (if the Measurement Computing device supports it and the appropriate switches are set on the device), all of the D/A voltages are updated simultaneously when the last D/A in the scan is updated. This generally means that all the D/A values are written to the Measurement Computing device, then a read of a D/A address causes all D/As to be updated with new values simultaneously.
ExtClock - When this option is used, then conversions are paced by the signal on the clock input line rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (see the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing device). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal. Options for the device default to transfer types that allow the maximum conversion rate to be attained unless otherwise specified.
ExtTrigger - If this option is specified, the sampling does not begin until the trigger condition is met. On many Measurement Computing devices, this trigger condition is programmable (see method method and board-specific information for details).

remarks.note:
An error occurs if you specify a total D/A rate beyond the capability of the Measurement Computing device. For example, if you specify = 0, = 3 (four channels total), and = 100,000, and you are using a Measurement Computing device that can output a maximum of 330,000 samples per second, you get an error. You have specified a total rate of 4*100,000 = 400,000.
The maximum output rate depends on both the D/A device being used and on the scan options. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the output rates of specific Measurement Computing D/A devices.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.APretrig(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,MccDaq.Range,System.Int32,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Waits for a trigger to occur and then returns a specified number of analog samples before and after the trigger occurred.
member.param: The number of the first A/D channel to scan.
The number of the last A/D channel to scan.

The number of samples to collect before the trigger occurs. Must be less than the ( – 512).
Upon return, contains the actual number of pre-trigger samples collected.

Total number of A/D samples to collect. Must be greater than or equal to the + 512.
Upon return, contains the actual number of samples collected.

Sample rate in scans per second per channel.
Upon return, contains the actual sample rate in scans per second per channel.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Handle for the Windows buffer used to to store data. This buffer must have been previously allocated with the method.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

remarks.note: The buffer referenced by the data array must be big enough to hold at least +512 integers.

item.description: The maximum allowable / number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured.

If the trigger occurs too early, fewer than the requested number of pre-trigger samples are collected, and a error occurs. The is set to indicate how many samples were actually collected. The post-trigger samples are still collected, and is set to indicate how many samples were actually collected.

If only "polled gate" triggering is supported, the external trigger input must be at TTL low before this method is called, or a error occurs. The trigger occurs when the trigger condition is met. Refer to the method, your Measurement Computing device user's guide, and the Universal Library User's Guide for more details.

settings
ConvertData - Data is collected into a "circular" buffer. When the data collection is complete, the data is in the wrong order. Use the ConvertData option to automatically reorganize data in the correct order—and convert to 12-bit values if required—when the data acquisition is complete. Otherwise, call to reorganize the data. You cannot use the ConvertData option in combination with the Background option.
Background - If the Background option is not used, the APretrig method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program, and the data collection from the A/D into the buffer continues in the background. Use method to check on the status of the background operation. Alternatively, some Measurement Computing devices support method for event notification of changes in status of Background scans. Use method to terminate the background process before it has completed.
Call method after normal termination of all background methods to clear variables and flags. You cannot use the ConvertData option in combination with the Background option for this function. To correctly order and parse the data, use method after the method completes.
ExtClock - This option is available only for Measurement Computing devices that have separate inputs for external pacer and external trigger.
Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing product.
ExtMemory - If you use this option to send the data to a MEGA-FIFO memory board, then you must use method to later read the pre-trigger data from the memory board. If you use method, the data is not, in the correct order.
Every time this option is used, it overwrites any data already stored in the memory board. All data should be read from the board (with MemReadPretrig) before collecting any new data. When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The MEGA-FIFO memory must be fully populated in order to use the APretrig method with the ExtMemory option.
DTConnect - When the DtConnect option is used with this method the data from ALL A/D conversions is sent out the DT-CONNECT interface. While this method is waiting for a trigger to occur, it will send data out the DT-CONNECT interface continuously. If you have a Measurement Computing memory device plugged into the DT-CONNECT interface then you should use the ExtMemory option rather than this option.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.ATrig(System.Int32,MccDaq.TriggerType,System.Int16,MccDaq.Range,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Waits for a specified analog input channel to go above or below a specified value.
member.param: Set the A/D channel number.
A that sets whether to wait for the analog input to be above or below .
The threshold value that all A/D values are compared to. Must be in the range 0 - 4095 for 12-bit A/D boards, or 0-65,535 for 16-bit A/D boards.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Upon return, contains the value of the first A/D sample to meet the trigger criteria.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

remarks.note:
When using this method in Windows programs, all active windows, along with keyboard and mouse activity, are locked until the trigger condition is satisfied.
Pressing Ctrl-Cdoes not terminate the waiting time for an analog trigger to meet the specified condition. There are only two ways to terminate this call: satisfy the trigger condition, or restart the computer.

item.description: ATrig continuously reads the specified channel and compares its value to the parameter. Depending on whether is set to TrigAbove or TrigBelow, it waits for the first A/D sample that is above or below . The first sample that meets the trigger criteria is returned to .

The maximum allowable number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured. Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your Measurement Computing product.

If the selected A/D device does not have a programmable gain feature, the parameter is ignored.
If the A/D device does have programmable gain, set the parameter to the desired A/D range. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the supported A/D ranges of each Measurement Computing A/D device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.C7266Config(System.Int32,MccDaq.Quadrature,MccDaq.CountingMode,MccDaq.DataEncoding,MccDaq.IndexMode,MccDaq.OptionState,MccDaq.FlagPins,MccDaq.OptionState)
member.summary: Configures a 7266 counter for desired operation. This method can only be used with Measurement Computing devices that contain a 7266 counter chip (quadrature encoder devices).
member.param: The number (1 to n) of the counter to configure, where n is the number of counters on the Measurement Computing counter device.
that sets the resolution multiplier for quadrature input, or disables quadrature input.
that sets operating mode for the counter.
that sets the format used for data returned by a 7266 counter.
that sets the action to take when the index signal is received.
that sets whether the index is an active low input () or active high input ().
that selects the signals to route to the FLG1 and FLG2 pins.
that sets whether counting is gated () or not gated ().
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: The C7266Config method can only be used with Measurement Computing devices that contain a 7266 counter chip (quadrature encoder devices). For more information, refer to the LS7266R1 data sheet.

options
- Each counter operates as a 24-bit counter that rolls over to 0 when the maximum count is reached.
- An upper and lower limit is set, mimicking limit switches in the mechanical counterpart. The upper limit is set by loading the PRESET register with the method after the counter has been configured. The lower limit is always 0. When counting up, the counter freezes whenever the count reaches the value that was loaded into the PRESET register. When counting down, the counter freezes at 0. In either case the counting is resumed only when the count direction is reversed.
- The counter is disabled whenever a count overflow or underflow takes place. The counter is re-enabled when a reset or load operation is performed on the counter.
- An upper limit is set by loading the PRESET register with a maximum count. When counting up, if the maximum count is reached, the counter rolls-over to 0 and continues counting up. When counting down, if the count reaches 0, it rolls-over to the maximum count (in the PRESET register) and continues counting down.

options
- The index signal is ignored.
- The counter is loaded whenever the index signal on the LCNTR pin occurs.
- The current count is latched whenever the index signal on the LCNTR pin occurs. When this mode is selected, the method returns the same count each time it is called until the index signal occurs.
- The counter is reset to 0 whenever the index signal on the RCNTR pin occurs.

options
- FLG1 pin is carry output, FLG2 is borrow output.
- FLG1 pin is compare output, FLG2 is borrow output.
- FLG1 pin is carry/borrow output, FLG2 is up/down signal.
- FLG1 is index output, FLG2 is error output.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.C8254Config(System.Int32,MccDaq.C8254Mode)
member.summary: Configures an 82C54 counter for desired operation.
member.param: The number (1 to n) of the counter to configure, where n is the number of counters on the Measurement Computing counter device.
that sets the operation mode of an 82C54 counter.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: The C8254Config method can only be used with Measurement Computing devices that contain an 82C54 counter chip. For more information, refer to the 82C54 data sheet.

options
- Output of counter (OUT N) transitions from low to high on terminal count and remains high until reset. See Mode 0 on 8254 data sheet.
- Output of counter (OUT N) transitions from high to low on rising edge of GATE N, then back to high on terminal count. See mode 1 on 8254 data sheet.
- Output of counter (OUT N) pulses low for one clock cycle on terminal count, reloads counter and recycles. See mode 2 on 8254 data sheet.
- Output of counter (OUT N) is high for count less than 1/2 terminal count, and then low until terminal count, whereupon it recycles. This mode generates a square wave. See mode 3 on 8254 data sheet.
- Output of counter (OUT N) pulses low for one clock cycle on terminal count. Count starts after counter is loaded. See mode 4 on 8254 data sheet.
- Output of counter (OUT N) pulses low for one clock cycle on terminal count. Count starts on rising edge at GATE N input. See mode 5 on 8254 data sheet.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CFreqIn(MccDaq.SignalSource,System.Int32,System.Int16@,System.Int32@)

member.param: that sets the source of the signal used to calculate the frequency.
Specifies the number of milliseconds that the counter counts.
Upon return, contains the raw count.
Upon return, contains the measured frequency in Hz.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description:
parameter options
One 9513 chip (chip 1 used):
Gate1 through Gate4
Freq1 through Freq5
CtrInput1 through CtrInput5
Two 9513 chips (chip 1 or chip 2 used):
CtrInput1 through CtrInput10
Gate1 through Gate9 (excluding Gate5)
Freq1 through Freq10
Four 9513 chips (chips 1- 4 can be used):
CtrInput1 through CtrInput20
Gate1 through Gate19 (excluding gates 5, 10 and 15)
Freq1 through Freq20
This method requires an electrical connection between counter 4 output and counter 5 gate. This connection must be made between counters 4 and 5 on the chip specified by .
Call C9513Init for each used by this method. The values of , , , , and are irrelevant to this method and may be any value shown in the method topic.

If you select an external clock source for the counters, the , , and settings are only valid if the external source is 1 MHz. Otherwise, you need to scale the values according to the frequency of the external clock source.
For example, for an external clock source of 2 MHz, increase your setting by a factor of 2, and also double the and values returned when analyzing your results.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CIn(System.Int32,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Reads the current count from a counter.
member.param: The counter to read current count from. Valid settings are 1 to 20, depending on the number of counters on the board.
Upon return, contains the counter value.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation
member.remarks: CIn vs. method: Although the CIn and CIn32 methods perform the same operation, CIn32 is the preferred method to use. The only difference between the two is that CIn returns a 16-bit count value and CIn32 returns a 32-bit value. Both CIn and CIn32 can be used, but CIn32 is required whenever you need to read count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

member.param: The number of the counter whose current count you want to read. Valid settings are 1 to n, where n is the number of counters on the Measurement Computing counter device..
Upon return, contains the current counter value.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation
member.remarks: method vs. CIn32: Although the CIn and CIn32 methods perform the same operation, CIn32 is the preferred method to use. The only difference between the two is that CIn returns a 16-bit count value and CIn32 returns a 32-bit value. Both CIn and CIn32 can be used, but CIn32 is required whenever you need to read count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CLoad(MccDaq.CounterRegister,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads a specified counter's Load, Hold, Alarm, QuadCount, QuadPreset or PreScaler register with a count.
member.param: used to set the register you that want to load with a count.
The count value to load. Count must be between 0 and 2resolution–1 of the counter.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description:
parameter values
to - Loads registers 1 to 20. Can span several chips.
to - Hold registers 1 to 20. Can span several chips (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the first counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the first counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the 2nd counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the 2nd counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the third counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the third counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the four counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the four counter chip. (9513 only).
to - Current count (LS7266 only).
to - Preset register (LS7266 only).
to - Prescaler register (LS7266 only).
You cannot load a count-down-only counter with less than 2.
There are several counter types supported. Please refer to the data sheet for the registers available for a counter type.

When loading a counter with a starting value, the value is never loaded directly into the counter's count register. Instead, it is loaded into the "load" or "hold" register. From there, once the counter is enabled, it loads the count from the appropriate register—usually on the first valid pulse.

CLoad vs. method: Although the CLoad and CLoad32 methods perform the same operation, the difference between the two is that CLoad loads a 16-bit count value and CLoad32 loads a 32-bit value. Both CLoad and CLoad32 can be used, but CLoad32 is required whenever you need to load count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

parameter options:
- Set to 1 whenever the count decrements past 0. Cleared to 0 whenever CStatus is called.
- Set to 1 whenever the count increments past it's upper limit. Cleared to 0 whenever CStatus is called.
- Set to 1 whenever the count matches the preset register. Cleared to 0 whenever CStatus is called.

- Set to 1 whenever an error occurs due to excessive noise on the input. Is cleared to 0 by calling method.
- Set to 1 when counting up. Cleared to 0 when counting down.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CStoreOnInt(System.Int32,MccDaq.CounterControl@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Installs an interrupt handler that stores the current count whenever an interrupt occurs.
member.param: The number of interrupts that stop the counter from being read. Counters are read every time an interrupt occurs until this number of interrupts is reached.
array that sets whether each channel's count is read or not read when an interrupt occurs.
The handle for the Windows buffer that stores the counts.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description:
If = 0, the method runs until method is called (refer to the remark below).
If is not zero, the array must be allocated to (* Number of Counters).
For example, if is set to 100 for a Measurement Computing device with five counters, then the array must be declared with a size of (100 * 5) = 500. This functionality keeps the user application from having to move the data out of the buffer for every interrupt before it is overwritten. For each interrupt, the counter values are stored in adjacent memory locations in the array.
Specifying as a non-zero value and failing to allocate the proper sized array results in a runtime error. There is no way for the Universal Library to determine if the array has been allocated with the proper size.

The array should have an element for each counter on the board (five elements for a five-channel Measurement Computing counter device, 10 elements for a 10-channel Measurement Computing counter device, and so on). Each element corresponds to a counter channel. Each element should be set to either or .
All channels set to Enabled are read when an interrupt occurs. The count value is stored in the element associated with that channel.

If = 0, then the array should have an element for each counter on the Measurement Computing device (five elements for a five-channel Measurement Computing counter device, 10 elements for a 10-channel Measurement Computing counter device, and so on). Each element corresponds to a counter channel. Each channel that is marked as Enabledin the array is read when an interrupt occurs. The count value is stored in the DataBuffer element associated with that channel.

The handle for the Windows buffer used to store and return data.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.

item.description:
Both and are zero-based, so the first counter number is 0.
The maximum allowable channel for both and depends on how many scan counters are available on the Measurement Computing device in use.
If more than one channel is being sampled, the number of samples collected per channel equals /(- + 1).

parameter values
- When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program and the data collection from the counter into the buffer continues in the background. If the Background option is not used, the CInScan method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. Use to check on the status of the background operation. Use with to stop the background process before it has completed. Execute after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This setting puts the method in an endless loop. Once it collects the required number of samples, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is by calling with . Normally, you should use this setting with so that your program regains control.
- If this option is specified, sampling does not begin until the trigger condition is met. You can set the trigger condition to rising edge, falling edge, or the level of the digital trigger input with the method. Refer to information on your Measurement Computing device in the Universal Library User's Guide.
The buffer must be previously allocated with .

setting used to bypass the setting, or to set a channel's comparitor output to one of 16 debounce times. Debounce is used to eliminate switch-induced transients typically associated with electro-mechanical devices including relays, proximity switches, and encoders.
setting that sets the mode of the debounce module.
setting that sets which edge to detect.
Reserved for future use.
Used to select the mapped counter channel. A mapped channel is another counter input channel that can participate in the channel's input signal by gating the counter.
member.returns: object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: This method only works with Measurement Computing counter devices that have counter scan capability. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which devices have this capability.
is zero based. The first counter number to clear is 0.

parameter options
- The counter is cleared at the beginning of every sample.
- The counter stops at the top of its count. The top of the count is FFFFFFFF hex.
- Allows the mapped channel to decrement the counter. Not compatible with or .
- Enables the counter when the mapped channel that is used to gate the counter is high. When the mapped channel is low, the counter is disabled (but holds the count value).
- Causes the count to be latched by the signal on the mapped counter. Not compatible with or .
- Selects a 32-bit counter.

parameter options
- Use this mode to reject glitches and pass state transitions only after a specified period of stability (as set by the parameter). This mode is used with electro-mechanical devices like encoders and mechanical switches to reject switch bounce and disturbances due to a vibrating encoder that is not otherwise moving. The debounce time should be set short enough to accept the desired inpulse, but longer than the period of the undesired disturbance.
- Use this mode when the input signal has groups of glitches, and each group is to be counted as one. The trigger before stable mode recognizes and counts the first glitch within a group, but rejects the subsequent glitches within the group if is set accordingly. In this case, is to encompass one entire group of glitches.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.DBitIn(MccDaq.DigitalPortType,System.Int32,MccDaq.DigitalLogicState@)
member.summary: Reads the state of a single digital input bit.
member.param: that sets the type of digital port from which to read a bit.
The number of the bit to read within the single large port.
Upon return, contains the bit value read (0 or 1).
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: This method treats all of the DIO ports of a particular type on a Measurement Computing device as a single port. It lets you read the state of any individual bit within this port. Note that for some port types, such as 8255 ports, if the port is configured for DigitalOut, this method provides readback of the last output value.

parameter options ()
There are three general types of digital ports:
ports that are programmable as input or output
ports that are fixed input or output
ports which you can program each bit as input or output
For the first of these types, set to .
For the latter two port types, set to . For Measurement Computing devices that have both types of digital ports, set to either or , depending on which digital inputs you want to read.
The tables below show how bit numbers are referenced throughout multiple 82C55 and 8536 digital chips. The maximum number of 82C55 chips on a single Measurement Computing product is eight, and the maximum number of 8536 chips on a single Measurement Computing product is two.

A of 0 indicates a logic low reading.
A of 1 indicates a logic high reading.
Logic high does not necessarily mean 5 V. Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide for chip input specifications.

member.summary: Configures a specific digital port as input or output.
member.param: The number of the port to configure.
that configures the the entire 8-bit or 4-bit bit for output () or input ().
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: This method is for use with ports that may be programmed as input or output, such as those on the 82C55 chips and 8536 chips. Refer to you Measurement Computing device user's manual for details of chip operation.

For most Measurement Computing devices, AuxPort is not configurable, so please consult your Measurement Computing device user's guide. The following tables show which ports and bit numbers are in which 82C55 and 8536 digital chips. The most 82C55 chips on a single Measurement Computing device is eight (8). The most 8536 chips found on a Measurement Computing device is two (2).
Refer to the device-specific information in the Universal Library User's Guide to determine if AuxPort should be configured for your product.

When used on ports within an 8255 chip, this method resets all ports on that chip configured for output to a zero state. If you set an output value on FirstPortA and then change the configuration on FirstPortB from output to input, the output value at FirstPortA is all zeros. You can, however, set the configuration on SecondPortX without affecting the value at FirstPortA. For this reason, this method is usually called at the beginning of the program for each port requiring configuration.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.DInScan(MccDaq.DigitalPortType,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Performs multiple reads of a digital input port of a high-speed digital port on a Measurement Computing device with a pacer clock.
member.param: that sets the digital I/O port to read (usually, or ). The selected port must be configured as an input.
The number of times to read the digital input port.

The number of times per second (Hz) to read the digital input port.
Upon return, contains the actual rate used in the scan.
The handle for the Windows buffer that stores digital data. This buffer must have been previously allocated with the method.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: The actual sampling rate is returned to the parameter because in some cases, the actual rate varies a small amount from the requested rate.

settings
- If the Background option is not used, the DInScan method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program and the data collection from the digital input port into the buffer continues in the background. Use method to check on the status of the background operation. Use method to stop the background process before it has completed. StopBackground should be executed after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it transfers the required number of bytes, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with method. Normally, this option is used with the Background option so that your program regains control.
- If this option is used, then transfers are controlled by the signal on the clock input line rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each transfer is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (see the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing device). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The transfer rate depends on the clock signal.
- Normally this method writes a single (byte) port. If WordXfer is specified, the two adjacent ports are read on each read, and the value of both ports together is stored as the low and high byte of a single array element in the buffer.
A transfer method cannot be specified. DMA is used.

bit fields that set various scanning modes.

settings
- If the Background option is not used, the DOutScan method does not return to your program until all of the data has been output. When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program and the transfer of the data from the buffer to the digital output port continues in the background. Use method to check on the status of the background operation. Use method to stop the background process before it has completed. StopBackground should be executed after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it transfers the required number of bytes, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with method. Normally, this option is used with the Background option so that your program regains control.
- If this option is used, then transfers are controlled by the signal on the clock input line rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each transfer is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (see the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing device). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The transfer rate depends on the clock signal.
- Normally this method writes to a single (byte) port. If WordXfer is specified, the two adjacent ports are written to on each write, and the value of both ports together is output as the low and high byte of a single array element in the buffer.
ByteXfer is the default setting. Make sure you are using an array when your data is arranged in bytes. Use the option for word array transfers.
