member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.FileAInScan(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,MccDaq.Range,System.String,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Scans a range of A/D channels and stores the samples in a disk file.
member.param: The number of the first A/D channel to scan.
The number of the last A/D channel to scan.
The number of A/D samples to collect.

param.name: rate
param.para: The sample rate—in scans per second per channel— of the scan.
Upon return, contains the actual sample rate in scans per second per channel.

member.param: A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
The name of the file used to store data. If the file does not exist, it is created.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: The maximum allowable / number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured.

parameter settings ( )
- If this option is used, then transfers are controlled by the signal on the clock input line rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each transfer is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (see the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing device). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal.
- If this option is specified, the sampling does not begin until the trigger condition is met. On many devices, this trigger condition is programmable (refer to method and the Universal Library User's Guide for information on specific Measurement Computing A/D devices).
On other devices, only "polled gate"' triggering is supported. In this case, assuming active high operation, data acquisition starts immediately if the trigger input is high. If the trigger input is low, acquisition is held off unit until it goes high. Acquisition continues until samples have been taken regardless of the state of the trigger input. This option is most useful if the signal is a pulse with a very low duty cycle (trigger signal in TTL low state most of the time) so that triggering is held off until the pulse occurs.
- Samples are sent to the DT-Connect port if the Measurement Computing device has one.

If an error occurs, it indicates that the data was not written to the file as fast as the data was sampled. Therefore, some data was lost. The value returned from method in totalCount is the number of points that were successfully collected.

remarks.note:
An error occurs if you specify a total A/D rate beyond the capability of the Measurement Computing device. For example, if you specify = 0, = 4 (five channels total) and = 20,000, and you are using a Measurement Computing device that can convert a maximum of 50,000 samples per second per channel, you get an error. You have specified a total rate of 5*20,000 = 100,000.
The maximum sampling rate depends on the Measurement Computing A/D device being used. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the sampling rates of your Measurement Computing A/D device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.FilePretrig(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,MccDaq.Range,System.String,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Waits for a trigger to occur and then returns a specified number of analog samples—including the specified number of pre-trigger samples—to a disk file.
member.param: The number of the first A/D channel to scan.
The number of the last A/D channel to scan.

The number of samples to collect before the trigger occurs. Must be less than the ( – 512).
Upon return, contains the actual number of pre-trigger samples collected.

Total number of A/D samples to collect. Must be greater than or equal to ( + 512).
Upon return, contains the actual number of samples collected.

Sample rate in scans per second.
Upon return, contains the actual sample rate in scans per second per channel.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
The name of the file used to store data. If the file does not exist, it is created.
bit fields that set various scanning modes.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

remarks.note: This method creates a buffer in memory that can hold + 512 integers.

item.description:
FilePretrig waits for a trigger signal to occur on the Trigger Input. Once the trigger occurs, it returns the specified number () of A/D samples, including the specified number of pre-trigger points.
It collects the data at the specified sampling and from the specified channel range ( - ) of A/D channels from the specified Measurement Computing device. If the A/D device has programmable gain, then it sets the gain to the specified . The collected data is returned to a file. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to determine if this method is supported by your device.

The maximum allowable / number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured.

If the trigger occurs too early, fewer than the requested number of pre-trigger samples are collected, and a error occurs. The is set to indicate how many samples were actually collected. The post-trigger samples are still collected, and is set to indicate how many samples were actually collected.
must be less than – 512.

settings
- If this option is used, then conversions are controlled by the signal on the clock input line rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal (refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide). When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal.
- Samples are sent to the DT-Connect port if the Measurement Computing device has one.
Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your particular Measurement Computing product.

If an error occurs, it indicates that the data was not written to the file as fast as the data was sampled. Therefore, some data was lost. The value returned from method in totalCount is the number of points that were successfully collected.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.GetStatus(System.Int16@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,MccDaq.FunctionType)
member.summary: Returns the status about the background operation currently running.
member.param: Upon return, contains a constant that indicates whether a background process is currently executing () or not executing ().
Upon return, contains the number of points that have been input or output since the process started.
Upon return, contains an index into the Windows data buffer.
that specifies the scan whose status information you want to retrieve.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description:
Use the parameter to gauge how far along the operation is towards completion. Generally, returns the total number of samples transferred between the Measurement Computing device and the Windows data buffer at the time GetStatus was called. When you set both the and Background options, 's behavior depends on the Measurement Computing device model.
Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn how your device behaves. With recent Measurement Computing DAQ designs, the parameter continually increases in increments of the packet size as Windows' circular data buffer recycles, until it reaches 231. Since the parameter is a signed integer, at 2,147,483,647 + 1, the parameter rolls back to a negative number (–2,147,483,647). The parameter resumes incrementing, eventually reaching 0 and increasing back up to 2,147,483,647. The parameter is usually more useful than the parameter in managing data collected when you set both the Continuous and Background options.

The parameter points to the start of the last completed channel scan that was transferred between the Measurement Computing device and the Windows data buffer. If no points in the buffer have been transferred, equals –1.
For Background operations, rolls over when the Windows data buffer is full. This rollover indicates that "new" data is now overwriting "old" data. Your goal is to process the old data before it gets overwritten. You can keep ahead of the data flow by copying the old data out of the buffer before new data overwrites it. The parameter can help you access the most recently transferred data. Your application does not have to process the data exactly when it becomes available in the buffer—in fact, you should avoid doing so unless absolutely necessary. The parameter generally increments by the packet size, but in some cases can vary within the same scan. One instance of a variable increment is when the packet size is not evenly divisible by the number of channels. You should determine the best size of the "chunks" of data that your application can most efficiently process, and then periodically check on the value to determine when that amount of additional data has been transferred.
Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your device, particularly when using pre-trigger.

parameter options:

- Specifies digital input scans started with method.
- Specifies digital output scans started with method.
- Specifies counter background operations started with method or method.

- Specifies a synchronous output scan started with .

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.TIn(System.Int32,MccDaq.TempScale,System.Single@,MccDaq.ThermocoupleOptions)
member.summary: Reads an analog input channel, linearizes it according to the selected temperature sensor type, and returns the temperature in degrees.
member.param: Number of the input channel to read.
that sets the temperature scale—, , or —used to convert the input.
Upon return, contains the temperature value in the selected scale.
bit fields that enable or disable filters.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: Thermocouple resolution for is approximately 0.25 °C, depending on scale, range and thermocouple type. RTD resolution is 0.1 °C.

parameter options
- When selected, a smoothing function is applied to temperature readings, very much like the electrical smoothing inherent in all hand-held temperature sensor instruments. This is the default. Ten samples are read from the specified channel and averaged. The average is the reading returned. Averaging removes normally distributed signal line noise.
- When selected, the temperature readings are not smoothed, resulting in a scattering of readings around a mean.

For Measurement Computing expansion devices, is calculated using the following formula, where:
"ADChan" is the A/D channel that is connected to the multiplexer.
"MuxChan" is a number ranging from 0 to 15 that specifies the channel number on a particular bank of the multiplexer.
= (ADChan * 16) + (16 + (MuxChan )
For example, you have a 16-channel Measurement Computing expansion device connected to channel 0 of an eight-channel Measurement Computing A/D device (with the channels numbered 0 -7). If you connect a thermocouple to channel 5 of the expansion device, would be (0 * 16) + (16 + 5)= 0 + 21 = 21.

The Cold Junction Compensation (CJC) channel is set in the InstaCal program. If you have multiple Measurement Computing expansion devices, the Universal Library (UL) applies the CJC reading to the linearization formula in the following manner:
If you selected a CJC channel for the expansion device that contains the channel you are reading, it uses the CJC temp reading from that channel.
If the CJC channel is not set on the expansion device that contains the channel you are reading, the UL uses the CJC reading from the next lower expansion device with a CJC channel selected.
For example, you have four 16-channel Measurement Computing expansion devices connected to channel 0, 1, 2 and 3 of an eight-channel Measurement Computing A/D device. You configure expansion device 1 (connected to channel 0) to have its CJC read on channel 7 of the Measurement Computing A/D device. You do not set the CJC channels on expansion devices 2, 3 and 4. Expansion devices 2, 3 and 4 all use the CJC reading from expansion device 1, and connect to channel 7 for linearization.
Keep the expansion devices in the same case and out of any breezes to ensure a clean CJC reading.
If a Measurement Computing expansion device is connected to an A/D device that does not have programmable gain, then the A/D device range is read from the configuration file (CB.CFG). In most cases, hardware-selectable ranges should be set to ±5 V for thermocouples and 0-10 V for RTDs.
Refer to your Measurement Computing device manual or the Universal Library User's Guide. If the device does have programmable RTDs gains, the TIn sets the appropriate A/D range.
If an or error occurs, the value returned is –9999.0.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.MemReset
member.summary: Resets a Measurement Computing memory device reference to the start of the memory.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: Measurement Computing memory devices are sequential devices. They contain a counter which points to the "current" word in memory. Every time a word is read or written, the counter increments to the next word.

Use this method to reset the counter back to the start of the memory. Between successive calls to the method, you should call this method so that the second AInScan overwrites the data from the first call. Otherwise, the data from the first AInScan is followed by the data from the second AInScan in the memory on the device.
Similarly, anytime you call method or call method ,the counter is left pointing to the next memory location after the data that you read or wrote. Call MemReset to reset back to the start of the memory buffer before the next call to AInScan.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.MemRead(System.Int16@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads data from a Measurement Computing memory device into an array.
member.param: Upon return, contains the array of data read from the Measurement Computing memory device.
The index of the first point to read, or .
Number of data points (words) to read.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

remarks.note: Do not call the MemRead method can while a DT-Connect transfer is in progress. For example, if you call method to start collecting A/D data in the background to a Measurement Computing memory device (with the + options) you cannot call MemRead until the AInScan has completed. If you do, a error occurs.

item.description:
To read a large amount of data in small chunks from a Measurement Computing memory device, set to FromHere to read each successive chunk. Using FromHere speeds up the operation of MemRead when working with large amounts of data.
For example, to read 300,000 points in 100,000 point chunks, the calls would look like this:
DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, 0, 100000) DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, FromHere, 1000000) DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, FromHere, 1000000)
Use the parameter to specify the first point to be read. For example, to read data sample numbers 200 through 249, set = 200 and = 50.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.InByte(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a byte from a hardware register on a Measurement Computing device.
member.param: Number of the Measurement Computing device register to read.
member.returns: The current value of the selected register

item.description: InByte is used to read 8-bit ports. method is used to read 16-bit ports. This method was designed for use with ISA bus boards. Use with PCI bus boards is not recommended.

The registers on Measurement Computing devices are at addresses that are offsets from the base address of the device (BaseAdr + 0, BaseAdr + 2, and so on). Set the parameter to the offset for the desired register. This method takes care of adding the base address to the offset, so that the device's address can be changed without changing the code.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.SetTrigger(MccDaq.TriggerType,System.Int16,System.Int16)
member.summary: Selects the trigger source and sets up the parameters used to initiate analog-to-digital conversions for the method (if the option is selected), method, method, and method (if the option is selected).
member.param: that sets the type of triggering based on the external trigger source
The low threshold used when the trigger input is analog.
The high threshold used when the trigger input is analog.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: parameter options:

The and ranges depend upon the resolution of the trigger circuitry. Must be 0 to 255 for 8-bit trigger circuits, 0 to 4095 for 12-bit trigger circuits, and 0 to 65535 for 16-bit trigger circuits.
If you are using signed integer types, the thresholds range from –32768 to 32767 for 16-bit Measurement Computing devices, instead of from 0 to 65535. In this case, the unsigned value of 65535 corresponds to a value of –1, 65534 corresponds to –2, …, 32768 corresponds to –32768.
For most Measurement Computing devices that support analog triggering, you can pass the required trigger voltage level and the appropriate Range to method to calculate the and values.
For some Measurement Computing devices (refer to the "Analog Input Boards" chapter in the Universal Library User's Guide), you must manually calculate the threshold by first calculating the least significant bit (LSB) for a particular range for the trigger resolution of your device. You then use the LSB to find the threshold in counts based on an analog voltage trigger threshold.
To calculate the threshold, do the following:
Calculate the LSB by dividing the full scale range (FSR) by 2resolution. FSR is the entire span from – FS to +FS of your Measurement Computing device for a particular range. For example, the full scale range of ±10 V is 20 V.
Calculate how many times you need to add the LSB calculated in step 1 to the negative full scale (–FS) to reach the trigger threshold value.
The maximum threshold value is 2resolution – 1. The formula is shown here:
Abs (–FS – threshold in volts) ÷ (LSB) = threshold in counts
Here are two examples that use this formula—one for 8-bit trigger resolution and one for 12-bit trigger resolution.
8-bit example using the ±10 V range with a –5 V threshold:
Calculate LSB: LSB = 20 ÷ 28 = 20 ÷ 256 = 0.078125
Calculate threshold: Abs(–10 – (–5)) ÷ .078125 = 5 ÷ 0.078125 = 64 (round this result if it is not an integer). A count of 64 translates to a voltage threshold of –5.0 V.
12-bit example using the ±10 V range with a +1 V threshold:
Calculate LSB: LSB = 20 ÷ 212 = 20 ÷ 4096 = 0.00488
Calculate threshold: Abs(–10 – 1) ÷ .00488 = 11 ÷ 0.00488 = 2254 (rounded from 2254.1). A count of 2254 translates to a voltage threshold of 0.99952 V.
Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your Measurement Computing device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.EnableEvent(MccDaq.EventType,System.Int32,MccDaq.EventCallback,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Binds one or more event conditions to a user-defined callback function. Upon detection of an event condition, the user-defined function is invoked with Measurement Computing device- and event-specific data.
member.param: that sets one or more event conditions to bind to the user-defined callback function.
Sets additional data needed to specify some event conditions, such as the event.
Specifies a delegate type that is the user-defined callback function to handle the parameter type(s).
Pointer to user-defined data that is passed to the delegate.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: EnableEvent detects event conditions in response to interrupts. Therefore, it is typically used with interrupt-driven processes such as method, method, or method.

parameter options
You can set more than one options by bitwise ORing the . If you specify an event that has not been enabled, no error occurs.
- Generates an event that occurs when a driver error is detected during input and output scans. This includes , , and errors.
- For some Measurement Computing digital and counter devices, this option generates an event that occurs when a pulse at the External Interrupt pin is detected.
- For method, generates an event that occurs when the first trigger is detected.
- Generates an event that occurs when the number of samples acquired during an analog input scan increases by ( method parameter) samples or more.
- Generates an event that occurs upon completion or fatal error of an method or method. This event does not occur when scans are aborted using StopBackground.
- Generates an event that occurs upon completion or fatal error of an AOutScan. This event does not occur when scans are aborted using StopBackground.

For events, is used to determine the minimum number of samples to acquire during an analog input scan before generating the event.
Most event conditions ignore this value.
A delegate is a data structure that refers either to a static method, or to a class instance and an instance method of that class. The parameter needs the same parameters as the delegate declaration.

EnableEvent cannot be called while any background operations ( method, method, or method) are active. If a background operation is in progress, when EnableEvent is called, it returns an error. You should perform a before calling EnableEvent.
Events can be generated no faster than the user callback function can handle them. If an event type becomes multi-signaled before the event handler returns, events are merged, such that the event handler is called once per event type, and the event handler is supplied with the event data corresponding to the latest event. In addition, if more than one event type becomes signaled, the event handler for each event type is called in the same order in which they are listed above. Events are generated while handling Measurement Computing device-generated interrupts. As a consequence, using StopBackground to abort background operations does not generate OnEndOfAoScan or OnEndOfAiScan events. However, the event handlers can be called directly immediately after calling StopBackground.
The parameter is not de-referenced by the library or its drivers; therefore, you can pass it a NULL pointer.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.SelectSignal(MccDaq.SignalDirection,MccDaq.SignalType,MccDaq.ConnectionPin,MccDaq.SignalPolarity)
member.summary:
Configures timing and control signals to use specific Auxiliary or DAQ Sync connections as a source or destination.
This method is intended for advanced users. Except for the input, you can easily configure all the timing and control signals using InstaCal.
member.param: that sets the direction of the signal type to assign to the connector pin ( = source signal, = destination signal).
that sets the signal to associate with the connector pin.
that sets the connection pin to associate with the and for the specified signal ().
that sets the polarity for the specified and .
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: For the settings of , and , you can also disable the external source by setting = (Disabled=0), so that it is neither input nor output. Set it in conjunction with the , , and parameters using the tables in the "SignalDirection, ConnectionPin, and SignalPolarity parameter options" remark below.

parameter options
- A/D conversion pulse or clock.
- External gate for A/D conversions.
- A/D channel scan signal.
- A/D scan completion signal.
- A/D simultaneous sample and hold signal.
- Start of A/D channel-scan sequence signal.
- A/D scan start trigger.
- A/D stop- or pre- trigger.
- A/D pacer timebase source.
- CTR1 clock source.
- CTR2 clock source.
- D/A start trigger.
- D/A pacer timebase source.
- D/A update signal.
- Digital ground.
- STC timebase signal.

, , and parameter options.
The following tables show the valid settings for the , , and parameters based on how the parameter is set.
You can view and edit the above timing and control configuration information from InstaCal. Open InstaCal, click on the Measurement Computing device, and click on the Configure... button or menu item. If the Measurement Computing device supports DAQ Sync and Auxiliary Input/Output signal connections, an Advanced Timing & Control Configuration button displays. Click on that button to open a form for viewing and modifying the above timing and control signals.
Except for the AdcTbSrc, DacTbsSrc and SyncClk signals, selecting an input signal connection does not necessarily activate it. Alternately, assigning an output signal to a connection does activate the signal upon performing the respective operation. For instance, when running an method, AdcConvert SignalIn selects the connection to use as an external clock to pace the A/D conversions; if AInScan is run without setting the ExtClock option, however, the selected connection is not activated and the signal at that connection is ignored. In both cases, the signal is output the connection(s) selected for the AdcConvert SignalOut. Since there are no scan options for enabling the Timebase Source and the SyncClk, selecting an input for the A/D or D/A Timebase Source, or SyncClk does activate the input source for the next respective operations.
Multiple input signals can be mapped to the same AuxIn connection by successive calls to SelectSignal; however, only one connection can be mapped to each input signal. If another connection had already been assigned to an input signal, the former selection is de-assigned and the new connection is assigned.
Only one output signal can be mapped to the same AuxOutn connection; however, multiple connections can be mapped to the same output signal by successive calls to method. If an output signal had already been assigned to a connection, then the former output signal is de-assigned and the new output signal is assigned to the connection.
When selecting for a signal, only one direction per signal type can be defined at a given time. Attempting to assign both directions of a signal to the DsConnector results in only the latest selection being applied. If the signal type had formerly been assigned an input direction from the DsConnector, assigning the output direction for that signal type results in the input signal being reassigned to its default connection.
and are intended to synchronize the timebase of the analog input and output pacers across two or more boards. Internal calculations of sampling and update rates assume that the external timebase has the same frequency as its internal clock. Adjust sample rates to compensate for differences in clock frequencies.
For instance, if the external timebase has a frequency of 10 MHz on a board that has a internal clock frequency of 40 MHz, the scan function samples or updates at a rate of about ¼ the rate entered. However, while compensating for differences in external timebase and internal clock frequency, if the rate entered results in an invalid pacer count, the method returns a error.

member.summary: Transfers integer values from a Windows memory buffer to a two-dimensional array as engineering units. The conversion from integer values to engineering unit values uses the A/D resolution of the Measurement Computing device associated with the object
member.param: The range to use for converting the scan data. This range should be the same as the range specified for the method.
The handle to the memory buffer holding the raw data to be converted to engineering units. Should equal the value returned by the method, and is provided to the scan function for storing data.
Array containing A/D input values converted to the equivalent engineering units based on the parameter. Allocate this array to be large enough to hold samples.
The index into the windows memory buffer that holds the first sample of the first channel to convert.

member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: WinBufToEngArray is usually used to get values from a Windows buffer containing data from a method such as , and make the data compatible with Measurement Studio waveform display controls. The converted values are transferred to the two-dimensional array based on the , , , and parameter settings.
The first dimension of the array should equal . The second dimension should equal .

The index into the raw memory that holds the first sample of the first channel to be converted equals * so that converted data always starts with the first channel specified in the scan.
For example, if is 14 and is 8, the index of the first converted sample is 112.

member.summary: Scans analog, digital, counter, and temperature input channels synchronously, and stores the samples in an array.
member.param: Array containing values from analog/temperature input channels, digital ports, and/or counters on the Measurement Computing device.
Array of elements, with each element defining the type of the corresponding element in .
Array of A/D range codes.
Number of elements in each array parameter—, , and .

Sets the rate (in samples per second) at which samples are taken.
Also returns the value of the actual rate used, which may be different from the requested rate because of pacer limitations.

Sets the number of pre-trigger samples to collect before the trigger occurs. Also returns the value of the actual pre-trigger count, which may be different from the requested pre-trigger count, because must be a multiple of the .
Sets the total number of samples to collect and store in the buffer.

bit fields that control various options.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: DaqInScan only works with Measurement Computing devices that support synchronous input. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which devices have this capability.

parameter options
- Analog input channel.
- 8-bit digital input port.
- 16-bit digital input port.
- 16-bit counter.
- Lower 16 bits of a 32-bit counter.
- Upper 16 bits of a 32-bit counter.
- CJC channel
- Thermocouple channel.
The TC channels must immediately follow their associated CJC channels in the channel array.
Use to convert raw thermocouple data to data on a temperature scale (Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin). If at least one TC channel is listed in the channel array, and averaging is enabled for that channel, the averaging is applied to all of the channels in the channel array.

A element is only valid if the corresponding element in is an analog input channel; otherwise, the range code for this channel is ignored.
Refer to the section covering your Measurement Computing device in the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which settings are supported.

This method won't run in pre-trigger mode if is set to zero, or if is less than .
The setting is ignored if the option is not specified.
must be evenly divisible by the number of channels being scanned (). If it is not, this method adjusts the number (down) to the next valid value, and returns that value to the parameter.

The setting must be greater than the setting.
must be evenly divisible by the number of channels being scanned (). If it is not, this method adjusts the number (down) to the next valid value and returns that value to the parameter.
The buffer must be previously allocated with or .

parameter values
- When the Background option is used, control returns immediately to the next line in your program and the data collection from the counter into the buffer continues in the background. If the Background option is not used, the DaqInScan method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. Use with to check on the status of the background operation. Use to stop the background process before it has completed. Execute after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it collects the required number of samples, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with the method. Normally, you should use this setting with so that your program regains control.
- If this option is specified, sampling does not begin until the trigger condition is met. You can set the trigger condition to rising edge, falling edge, or the level of the digital trigger input with the method. Refer to information on your Measurement Computing device in the Universal Library User's Guide.
- If this option is used, conversions are controlled by the signal on the external clock input rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal. When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal. Options for the board default to a transfer mode that allows the maximum conversion rate to be attained unless otherwise specified.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.DaqSetTrigger(MccDaq.TriggerSource,MccDaq.TriggerSensitivity,System.Int32,MccDaq.ChannelType,MccDaq.Range,System.Single,System.Single,MccDaq.TriggerEvent)
member.summary: Configures the trigger source used for synchronous data output.
member.param: External type used to start data acquisition.
mode used to set trigger sensitivity.
Trigger channel. This channel must be a configured channel included in the parameter set with .
setting of the configured trigger channel. must match the configured channel type set with .
Trigger channel gain code.
The level in engineering units to detect the trigger event. Used for input channel comparisons to detect the start trigger or stop trigger event
The amount in engineering units that the trigger event can vary from the level parameter.
mode that sets the type of trigger event.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: DaqSetTrigger only works with Measurement Computing devices that support synchronous input. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which devices have this capability.

If the Measurement Computing device has programmable gain, the parameter should match the gain code setting of the channel configured with the method.
is ignored if is not an analog channel.

parameter values
- Start trigger event only. Aquisition begins immediately when method is invoked. No pre-trigger data acquisition with this trigger type.
- Start trigger event only. Acquisition begins on the selectable edge of an external TTL signal. No pre-trigger data acquisition with this trigger type.
- Start trigger event only. Acquisition begins on the selected input signal criteria (above level, below level, rising edge, etc.) must be defined as the first channel in the channel scan group. No pre-trigger data acquisition with this trigger type.
- Post-trigger data acquisition begins on the selected input signal criteria (above level, below level, rising edge, etc.)
- Post-trigger data acquisition when a specified digital pattern is received on a specified digital port.
- Post-trigger data acquisition begins when specified counter criteria is detected.
- Stop trigger event only. Stops collecting post-trigger data when the specified number of post-trigger scans are completed.

parameter values
- Triggers when the signal goes from low to high (TTL trigger) or rises through a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, and counter).
- Triggers when the signal goes from high to low (TTL trigger) or falls through a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, and counter).
- Triggers when the signal is above a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, counter, and digital pattern).
- Triggers when the signal is below a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, counter, and digital pattern).
- Triggers when the signal is equal to a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, counter, and digital pattern).
- Triggers when the signal is not equal to a specified level (hardware analog, software analog, counter, and digital pattern).

parameter values
- Defines the conditions under which post-trigger acquisition data collection is initiated or triggered. The start trigger event can vary in complexity from starting immediately, to starting on complex channel value definitions.
- Signals the current data acquisition process to terminate. The stop trigger event can be as simple as that of a scan count, or as complex as involving a channel value level condition.

Possible values of the parameter based on the trigger source
TrigAnalogHW - The voltage used to define the trigger level. Trigger detection is performed in hardware.
TrigAnalogSW - The voltage used to define the trigger level. Trigger detection is performed in software.
TrigDigPattern - The bit pattern for the digital channel trigger. Choices are 0.0 (no bits set) or 255.0 (all bits set) for 8-bit digital ports, and 0.0 (no bits set) or 65,535.0 (all bits set) for 16-bit digital ports.
TrigCounter - Selects either Pulse or Totalize counter values (0.0 – 65,535).
TrigImmediate - Ignored
TrigScanCount - Ignored

Trigger start and stop criteria based on the selected trigger type () and trigger sensitivity ()
is TrigAnalogHW (Start trigger event only) and is:
RisingEdge: Triggers when the signal value is less than - . Then, the signal value is greater than .
FallingEdge: Triggers when the signal value is greater than + . Then, the signal value is less than .
AboveLevel: Triggers when the signal value is greater than .
BelowLevel: Triggers when the signal value is less than .
is TrigAnalogSW and is:
RisingEdge: Triggers/stops when the signal value is less than - . Then, the signal value is greater than .
FallingEdge: Triggers/stops when the signal value is greater than + . Then, the signal value is less than .
AboveLevel: Triggers/stops when the signal value is greater than .
BelowLevel: Triggers/stops when the signal value is less than .
EqLevel: Triggers/stops when ( - ) is less than the signal value, AND the signal value is less than ( + ).
NeLevel: Triggers/stops when the signal value is less than ( - ), OR when the signal value is greater than ( + ).
is TrigDigPattern and is:
AboveLevel: Triggers/stops when the (digital port value AND (bitwise) ) is greater than ( AND (bitwise) ).
BelowLevel: Triggers/stops when the (digital port value AND (bitwise) ) is less than ( AND (bitwise) ).
EqLevel: Triggers/stops when the (digital port value AND (bitwise) ) is equal to ( AND (bitwise) ).
NeLevel: Triggers/stops when the (digital port value AND (bitwise) ) is not equal to ( AND (bitwise) ).
is TrigCounter and is:
RisingEdge: Triggers/stops when the counter channel is less than - . Then, the counter channel is greater than .
FallingEdge: Triggers/stops when the counter channel is greater than + . Then, the counter channel is less than .
AboveLevel: Triggers/stops when the counter channel is greater than - .
BelowLevel: Triggers/stops when the counter channel is less than + .
EqLevel: Triggers/stops when ( - ) is less than the counter channel, AND the counter channel is less than ( + ).
NeLevel: Triggers/stops when the counter channel is less than ( - ), OR when the counter channel is greater than ( + ).

Number of setpoints (from 0 to 16) to configure. Set to 0 to disable setpoints.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: DaqSetSetpoints only works with Measurement Computing devices that support synchronous input. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which devices have this capability.

setpointFlag parameter values

- Setpoint criteria, where the input channel is greater than limit B.
- Setpoint criteria. If the input channel is greater than limit A, then output value 1. If the input channel is less than limit B, then output value 2.
- Setpoint criteria, where the input channel is greater than limit A and less than limit B.
- Setpoint criteria, where the input channel is less than limit A.
- Setpoint criteria, where the input channel is less than limit A and greater than limit B.
- Setpoint criteria. If the setpoint criteria is met then output value 1.
- Setpoint criteria. If the setpoint criteria is met then output value 1. If the setpoint criteria is not met then output value 2.

- Output to DAC0 when the criteria is met. The Measurement Computing device must have a DAC0 signal.
- Output to DAC1 when the criteria is met. The Measurement Computing device must have a DAC1 signal.
- Output to DAC2 when the criteria is met. The Measurement Computing device must have a DAC2 signal.
- Output to DAC3 when the criteria is met. The Measurement Computing device must have a DAC3 signal.
- Output to FIRSTPORTC when the criteria is met.
- Performs no outputs.
- Output to timer 0 when the criteria is met.
- Output to timer 1 when the criteria is met.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.DaqOutScan(System.Int16[],MccDaq.ChannelType[],MccDaq.Range[],System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.Int32,MccDaq.ScanOptions)
member.summary: Outputs data synchronously to analog output channels and digital output ports.
member.param: Array containing analog channel values and/or digital port values from a Measurement Computing device.
Array of elements, with each element defining the type of the corresponding element in .
Array of D/A codes.
Number of elements in each array parameter—, , and .

Sets the rate (in samples per second) at which samples are taken.
Also returns the value of the actual rate used, which may be different from the set rate because of pacer limitations.

Sets the total number of values to output.
Also returns the value of the actual count, which may be different from the set because must be a multiple of the channel count.
Sets the handle for the Windows buffer used to output the data.
bit fields that control various options.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: DaqOutScan only works with Measurement Computing devices that support synchronous output. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which devices have this capability.

parameter options
- Analog output channel.
- 16-bit digital output port (FirstPortA only).

A element is only valid if the corresponding element in is an analog output channel; otherwise, the range code for this channel is ignored.
This parameter is also ignored if the Measurement Computing device does not have programmable gain. In this case, it can be set to null.
Refer to the section covering your Measurement Computing device in the Universal Library User's Guide to learn which settings are supported.
The buffer must be previously allocated with , and loaded with values to output (for example, using .)

parameter values
- When the Background option is used, the output operations begin running in the background, and control returns immediately to the next line in your program. If the Background option is not used, the DaqInScan method does not return to your program until all of the requested data has been collected and returned to the buffer. Use with . to check on the status of the background operation. Use with DaqoFunction. to stop the background process before it has completed. Execute with DaqoFunction. after normal termination of all background functions in order to clear variables and flags.
- This option puts the method in an endless loop. Once it outputs the specified number ( of values, it resets to the start of the buffer and begins again. The only way to stop this operation is with the method with DaqoFunction. Normally, you should use this setting with so that your program regains control.
- If this option is used, conversions are controlled by the signal on the external clock input rather than by the internal pacer clock. Each conversion is triggered on the appropriate edge of the clock input signal. When this option is used, the parameter is ignored. The sampling rate depends on the clock signal. Options for the board default to a transfer mode that allows the maximum conversion rate to be attained unless otherwise specified.
- If this option is used, the data output operation is paced by the ADC clock.
- If this option is used, the data output operation is triggered when the ADC clock starts.
- This option allows non-streamed data output to be generated to the specified output channel.
In this mode, the aggregate size of data output buffer must be less than or equal to the size of the internal data output FIFO on the Measurement Computing device. This allows the data output buffer to be loaded into the device’s internal output FIFO.
Once the sample updates are transferred (or downloaded) to the device, the device is responsible for outputting the data. While the size is limited, and the output buffer cannot be changed once the output is started, this mode has the advantage of not having to periodically feed output data through the program to the device for the data output to continue.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.ACalibrateData(System.Int32,MccDaq.Range,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Calibrates the raw data collected by method from devices with real-time software calibration when the real-time calibration has been turned off. The AInScan method returns either raw A/D data or calibrated data, depending on whether or not the option was used.
member.param: The number of samples to calibrate.
The programmable gain/range used when the data was collected.
Upon return, contains the calibrated data.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks:
When collecting data using method with the NoCalibrateData option, use this method to calibrate the data after it is collected.
The name of array must match that used in AInScan.
Applying software calibration factors in real-time on a per-sample basis eats up machine cycles. If your CPU is slow, or if processing time is at a premium, withhold calibration until after the acquisition run is complete. Turning off real-time software calibration saves CPU time during a high-speed acquisition run.
Processor speed is a factor for DMA transfers and for real-time software calibration. Processors of less than 150 megahertz (MHz) Pentium class may impose speed limits below the capability of the Measurement Computing device (refer to your Measurement Computing device manual or the Universal Library User's Guide). If your processor is less than a 150 MHz Pentium, and you need an acquisition speed in excess of 200 kilohertz (kHz), use the NoCalibrateData option to a turn off real-time software calibration and save CPU time. After the acquisition is run, calibrate the data with ACalibrateData.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.AConvertData(System.Int32,System.UInt16@,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Converts the raw data collected by method into 12-bit A/D values. The AInScan method returns either raw A/D data or converted data, depending on whether or not the option is used. For many 12-bit A/D boards, the raw data is a 16-bit value that contains a 12-bit A/D value and a 4-bit channel tag (refer to your Measurement Computing device manual or the Universal Library User's Guide). The converted data consists of just the 12-bit A/D value.
member.param: The number of samples to convert.
The pointer to the start of the data array.
Upon return, contains the pointer to the start of the channel tag array (if available).
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks:
When collecting data using method without the ConvertData option, use this method to convert the data after it has been collected. There are cases where the ConvertData option is not allowed. For example, if you are using both the and options with AInScan. In those cases, this method should be used to convert the data after the data collection is complete.
For some boards, each raw data point consists of a 12-bit A/D value with a 4-bit channel number. This method pulls each data point apart and puts the A/D value into the adData array and the channel number into the array.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.AConvertPretrigData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.UInt16@,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Converts the raw data collected by the method.
member.param: The number of pre-trigger samples to convert. This number must match the number returned by the parameter in the method.
The total number of samples to convert.
The pointer to the data array. Array name must match the name of the array used with the method.

Upon return, contains the pointer to the start of the channel tag array (if available). Returns NULL if using a 16-bit board or if channel tags not available. Refer to 16-bit board information in "Remarks" section.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: The method returns either raw A/D data or converted data, depending on whether or not the option was used. The raw data is not in the correct order as it is collected. After the data collection is completed, it must be rearranged into the correct order. This method also orders the data, starting with the first pretrigger data point and ending with the last post-trigger point.

On some 12-bit A/D boards, each raw data point consists of a 12-bit A/D value with a 4-bit channel number. This method pulls each data point apart and puts the A/D value into the and the channel number into the array.
Upon returning from AConvertPretrigData, the array contains only 12-bit A/D data.
Use this method with 16-bit A/D boards only to order the data. No channel tags are returned.

VB .Net programmers: After the data is collected with the method, it must be copied to a BASIC array with the method.
The entire array must be copied, which includes the extra 512 samples needed by the method.

Expansion boards are also supported by this method, so this parameter can be set to up to 272. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on specific Measurement Computing expansion devices.

that sets the D/A range code. The output range of the D/A channel can be set to any of those supported by the Measurement Computing device. If the D/A device does not have programmable ranges, then this parameter is ignored.
Value to set D/A to. Must be in the range 0 - N where N is the value 2Resolution – 1 of the converter.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks: Simultaneous update devices: If you set the simultaneous update jumper for simultaneous operation, use method for simultaneous update of multiple channels. AOut always writes the D/A data, then reads the D/A, which causes the D/A output to be updated.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.ATrig(System.Int32,MccDaq.TriggerType,System.UInt16,MccDaq.Range,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Waits for a specified analog input channel to go above or below a specified value.
member.param: Set the A/D channel number.
A that sets whether to wait for the analog input to be above or below .
The threshold value that all A/D values are compared to. Must be in the range 0 - 4095 for 12-bit A/D boards, or 0-65,535 for 16-bit A/D boards.
A that sets the gain on the A/D board.
Upon return, contains the value of the first A/D sample to meet the trigger criteria.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

remarks.note:
When using this method in Windows programs, all active windows, along with keyboard and mouse activity, are locked until the trigger condition is satisfied.
Pressing Ctrl-Cdoes not terminate the waiting time for an analog trigger to meet the specified condition. There are only two ways to terminate this call: satisfy the trigger condition, or restart the computer.

item.description: ATrig continuously reads the specified channel and compares its value to the parameter. Depending on whether is set to TrigAbove or TrigBelow, it waits for the first A/D sample that is above or below . The first sample that meets the trigger criteria is returned to .

The maximum allowable number depends on the type of A/D device being used. For Measurement Computing devices with both single-ended and differential inputs, the maximum allowable channel number also depends on how the device is configured. Refer to your Measurement Computing device user's guide and the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your Measurement Computing product.

If the selected A/D device does not have a programmable gain feature, the parameter is ignored.
If the A/D device does have programmable gain, set the parameter to the desired A/D range. Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on the supported A/D ranges of each Measurement Computing A/D device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CFreqIn(MccDaq.SignalSource,System.Int32,System.UInt16@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Measures the frequency of a signal from a 9513 counter.
member.param: that sets the source of the signal used to calculate the frequency.
Specifies the number of milliseconds that the counter counts.
Upon return, contains the raw count.
Upon return, contains the measured frequency in Hz.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description:
parameter options
One 9513 chip (chip 1 used):
Gate1 through Gate4
Freq1 through Freq5
CtrInput1 through CtrInput5
Two 9513 chips (chip 1 or chip 2 used):
CtrInput1 through CtrInput10
Gate1 through Gate9 (excluding Gate5)
Freq1 through Freq10
Four 9513 chips (chips 1- 4 can be used):
CtrInput1 through CtrInput20
Gate1 through Gate19 (excluding gates 5, 10 and 15)
Freq1 through Freq20
This method requires an electrical connection between counter 4 output and counter 5 gate. This connection must be made between counters 4 and 5 on the chip specified by .
Call C9513Init for each used by this method. The values of , , , , and are irrelevant to this method and may be any value shown in the method topic.

If you select an external clock source for the counters, the , , and settings are only valid if the external source is 1 MHz. Otherwise, you need to scale the values according to the frequency of the external clock source.
For example, for an external clock source of 2 MHz, increase your setting by a factor of 2, and also double the and values returned when analyzing your results.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CIn(System.Int32,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Reads the current count from a counter.
member.param: The counter to read current count from. Valid settings are 1 to 20, depending on the number of counters on the board.
Upon return, contains the counter value.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation
member.remarks: CIn vs. method: Although the CIn and CIn32 methods perform the same operation, CIn32 is the preferred method to use. The only difference between the two is that CIn returns a 16-bit count value and CIn32 returns a 32-bit value. Both CIn and CIn32 can be used, but CIn32 is required whenever you need to read count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CIn32(System.Int32,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Reads the current count from a counter and returns it as a 32-bit integer.
member.param: The number of the counter whose current count you want to read. Valid settings are 1 to n, where n is the number of counters on the Measurement Computing counter device..
Upon return, contains the current counter value.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation
member.remarks: method vs. CIn32: Although the CIn and CIn32 methods perform the same operation, CIn32 is the preferred method to use. The only difference between the two is that CIn returns a 16-bit count value and CIn32 returns a 32-bit value. Both CIn and CIn32 can be used, but CIn32 is required whenever you need to read count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.CLoad(MccDaq.CounterRegister,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Loads a specified counter's Load, Hold, Alarm, QuadCount, QuadPreset or PreScaler register with a count.
member.param: used to set the register you that want to load with a count.
The count value to load. Count must be between 0 and 2resolution–1 of the counter.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description:
parameter values
to - Loads registers 1 to 20. Can span several chips.
to - Hold registers 1 to 20. Can span several chips (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the first counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the first counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the 2nd counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the 2nd counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the third counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the third counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 1 of the four counter chip. (9513 only).
- Alarm register 2 of the four counter chip. (9513 only).
to - Current count (LS7266 only).
to - Preset register (LS7266 only).
to - Prescaler register (LS7266 only).
You cannot load a count-down-only counter with less than 2.
There are several counter types supported. Please refer to the data sheet for the registers available for a counter type.

When loading a counter with a starting value, the value is never loaded directly into the counter's count register. Instead, it is loaded into the "load" or "hold" register. From there, once the counter is enabled, it loads the count from the appropriate register—usually on the first valid pulse.

CLoad vs. method: Although the CLoad and CLoad32 methods perform the same operation, the difference between the two is that CLoad loads a 16-bit count value and CLoad32 loads a 32-bit value. Both CLoad and CLoad32 can be used, but CLoad32 is required whenever you need to load count values greater than 16 bits (counts > 65535).

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.DIn(MccDaq.DigitalPortType,System.UInt16@)

The size of the ports vary.
If it is an eight-bit port, the returned value is in the 0 - 255 range.

item.description:
If the port type is not AuxPort, you must use method to configure the port for output first.
If the port type is AuxPort, you may need to use method or DConfigPort to configure the bit for output first.
Refer to the device-specific information in the the Universal Library User's Guide to determine if AuxPort should be configured for your product.

The size of the ports vary.
If it is an eight-bit port, the output value is in the 0 - 255 range.
If it is a four-bit port, the output value is in the 0 - 15 range.
Refer to the information for your Measurement Computing device in Universal Library User's Guide to learn about valid settings.

The following tables show which ports and bit numbers are in which 82C55 and 8536 digital chips. The most 82C55 chips on a single Measurement Computing device is eight (8). The most 8536 chips found on a Measurement Computing device is two (2).

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.MemRead(System.UInt16@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads data from a Measurement Computing memory device into an array.
member.param: Upon return, contains the array of data read from the Measurement Computing memory device.
The index of the first point to read, or .
Number of data points (words) to read.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

remarks.note: Do not call the MemRead method can while a DT-Connect transfer is in progress. For example, if you call method to start collecting A/D data in the background to a Measurement Computing memory device (with the + options) you cannot call MemRead until the AInScan has completed. If you do, a error occurs.

item.description:
To read a large amount of data in small chunks from a Measurement Computing memory device, set to FromHere to read each successive chunk. Using FromHere speeds up the operation of MemRead when working with large amounts of data.
For example, to read 300,000 points in 100,000 point chunks, the calls would look like this:
DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, 0, 100000) DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, FromHere, 1000000) DaqBoard0.MemRead (dataBuffer, FromHere, 1000000)
Use the parameter to specify the first point to be read. For example, to read data sample numbers 200 through 249, set = 200 and = 50.

Some Measurement Computing A/D devices have programmable voltage ranges, while others set the voltage range via switches. In either case, the selected range must be passed to this method. Refer to the hyperlink in the parameter description.

item.description: This method is typically used to obtain a voltage (or current) value from data received from an A/D with methods such as .

Use this method for devices with a resolution of 20-bits or more.
The default resolution of this method is 32-bits, so if the device has neither analog input nor analog output, the result is a 32-bit conversion.
If the device has both analog input and analog output, the resolution and transfer function of the D/A converter on the device is used for the conversion.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.SetTrigger(MccDaq.TriggerType,System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Selects the trigger source and sets up the parameters used to initiate analog-to-digital conversions for the method (if the option is selected), method, and methods.
member.param: that sets the type of triggering based on the external trigger source
The low threshold used when the trigger input is analog.
The high threshold used when the trigger input is analog.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: parameter options:

The and ranges depend upon the resolution of the trigger circuitry. Must be 0 to 255 for 8-bit trigger circuits, 0 to 4095 for 12-bit trigger circuits, and 0 to 65535 for 16-bit trigger circuits.
If you are using signed integer types, the thresholds range from –32768 to 32767 for 16-bit Measurement Computing devices, instead of from 0 to 65535. In this case, the unsigned value of 65535 corresponds to a value of –1, 65534 corresponds to –2, …, 32768 corresponds to –32768.
For most Measurement Computing devices that support analog triggering, you can pass the required trigger voltage level and the appropriate Range to method to calculate the and values.
For some Measurement Computing devices (refer to the "Analog Input Boards" chapter in the Universal Library User's Guide), you must manually calculate the threshold by first calculating the least significant bit (LSB) for a particular range for the trigger resolution of your device. You then use the LSB to find the threshold in counts based on an analog voltage trigger threshold.
To calculate the threshold, do the following:
Calculate the LSB by dividing the full scale range (FSR) by 2resolution. FSR is the entire span from – FS to +FS of your Measurement Computing device for a particular range. For example, the full scale range of ±10 V is 20 V.
Calculate how many times you need to add the LSB calculated in step 1 to the negative full scale (–FS) to reach the trigger threshold value.
The maximum threshold value is 2resolution – 1. The formula is shown here:
Abs (–FS – threshold in volts) ÷ (LSB) = threshold in counts
Here are two examples that use this formula—one for 8-bit trigger resolution and one for 12-bit trigger resolution.
8-bit example using the ±10 V range with a –5 V threshold:
Calculate LSB: LSB = 20 ÷ 28 = 20 ÷ 256 = 0.078125
Calculate threshold: Abs(–10 – (–5)) ÷ .078125 = 5 ÷ 0.078125 = 64 (round this result if it is not an integer). A count of 64 translates to a voltage threshold of –5.0 V.
12-bit example using the ±10 V range with a +1 V threshold:
Calculate LSB: LSB = 20 ÷ 212 = 20 ÷ 4096 = 0.00488
Calculate threshold: Abs(–10 – 1) ÷ .00488 = 11 ÷ 0.00488 = 2254 (rounded from 2254.1). A count of 2254 translates to a voltage threshold of 0.99952 V.
Refer to the Universal Library User's Guide for information on your Measurement Computing device.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccBoard.EnableEvent(MccDaq.EventType,System.UInt32,MccDaq.EventCallback,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Binds one or more event conditions to a user-defined callback function. Upon detection of an event condition, the user-defined function is invoked with Measurement Computing device- and event-specific data.
member.param: that sets one or more event conditions to bind to the user-defined callback function.
Sets additional data needed to specify some event conditions, such as the event.
Specifies a delegate type that is the user-defined callback function to handle the parameter type(s).
Pointer to user-defined data that is passed to the delegate.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation

item.description: EnableEvent detects event conditions in response to interrupts. Therefore, it is typically used with interrupt-driven processes such as method, method, or method.

parameter options
You can set more than one options by bitwise ORing the . If you specify an event that has not been enabled, no error occurs.
- Generates an event that occurs when a driver error is detected during input and output scans. This includes , , and errors.
- For some Measurement Computing digital and counter devices, this option generates an event that occurs when a pulse at the External Interrupt pin is detected.
- For method, generates an event that occurs when the first trigger is detected.
- Generates an event that occurs when the number of samples acquired during an analog input scan increases by ( method parameter) samples or more.
- Generates an event that occurs upon completion or fatal error of an method or method. This event does not occur when scans are aborted using StopBackground.
- Generates an event that occurs upon completion or fatal error of an AOutScan. This event does not occur when scans are aborted using StopBackground.

For events, is used to determine the minimum number of samples to acquire during an analog input scan before generating the event.
Most event conditions ignore this value.
A delegate is a data structure that refers either to a static method, or to a class instance and an instance method of that class. The parameter needs the same parameters as the delegate declaration.

EnableEvent cannot be called while any background operations ( method, method, or method) are active. If a background operation is in progress, when EnableEvent is called, it returns an error. You should perform a before calling EnableEvent.
Events can be generated no faster than the user callback function can handle them. If an event type becomes multi-signaled before the event handler returns, events are merged, such that the event handler is called once per event type, and the event handler is supplied with the event data corresponding to the latest event. In addition, if more than one event type becomes signaled, the event handler for each event type is called in the same order in which they are listed above. Events are generated while handling Measurement Computing device-generated interrupts. As a consequence, using StopBackground to abort background operations does not generate OnEndOfAoScan or OnEndOfAiScan events. However, the event handlers can be called directly immediately after calling StopBackground.
The parameter is not de-referenced by the library or its drivers; therefore, you can pass it a NULL pointer.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccService.ErrHandling(MccDaq.ErrorReporting,MccDaq.ErrorHandling)
member.summary: The error handling for all subsequent method calls. If the Universal Library cannot find the configuration file CB.CFG, it terminates the program, regardless of the ErrHandling setting.
member.param: Controls when the library prints error messages on the screen. Set to one of the constants in the "errorReporting parameter values" section below.
Specifies what class of error causes the program to halt. Set it to one of the constants in the "errorHandling parameter values" section below.
member.returns: Returns an object that always has MccDaq.ErrorInfo.= NoErrors
member.remarks:
errorReporting parameter values:
All of the errorReporting settings are MccDaq.ErrorReporting enumerated constants. To set a variable to one of these constants, refer to the MccDaq object and the ErrorReporting enumeration (variable = MccDaq.ErrorReporting.DontPrint, etc.).
- Errors do not generate a message to the screen. In this case, your program must always check the returned error code after each library call to determine if an error occurred.
- Only warning errors generate a message to the screen. Your program must check for fatal errors.
- Only fatal errors generate a message to the screen. Your program must check for warning errors.
- All errors generate a message to the screen.
errorHandling parameter values:
All of the errorReporting settings are MccDaq.ErrorHandling enumerated constants. To set a variable to one of these constants, refer to the MccDaq object and the ErrorHandling enumeration (variable = MccDaq.ErrorHandling.DontStop, and so on).
- The program always continues executing when an error occurs.
- The program halts if a "fatal" error occurs.
- Stop whenever any error occurs. You can check error codes to determine the cause of the error.
Warnings vs. fatal errors:
All errors that can occur are classified as either "warnings" or "fatal."
Errors that can occur in normal operation in a bug free program (disk is full, too few samples before trigger occurred) are classified as "warnings."
All other errors indicate a more serious problem and are classified as "fatal."

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccService.DeclareRevision(System.Single@)
member.summary: Initializes the Universal Library (UL) with the revision number of the library used to write your program.
member.param: Revision number of the UL used to interpret method parameters.
member.returns: Returns an object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: Must be the first Universal Library method to be called by your program.

Any program that uses the 32-bit library and that does not contain this line of code defaults to UL revision 5.4 parameter assignments.
As new revisions of the UL are released, bugs from previous revisions are fixed and occasionally new methods are added. It is National Instruments' goal to preserve existing programs you have written, and therefore you never have to change the order or number of parameters in a method.
With the DeclareRevision method, programs do not have to be rewritten in each line where new methods are used, and the program then recompiled. The revision control method initializes the DLL so that the methods are interpreted according to the format of the revision that you wrote and compiled your program in. The method works by interpreting the UL function call from your program and filling in any arguments needed to run with the new revision.
If your program has declared you are running code written for an earlier revision and you call a new method, you must rewrite your program to include the new parameter, and declare the current revision in DeclareRevision.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccService.GetBoardName(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the name of a specified Measurement Computing device.
member.param: Upon return, refers either to the board number associated with a board when it was installed, or .
Upon return, contains the null-terminated string variable containing the board name.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.
member.remarks:
There are two ways to use this function:
Pass a board number as the parameter. The string that is returned describes the type of the installed device.
Set to or to get a list of all board types that are supported by the library.
Set to GetFirst to get the first device type in the list of Measurement Computing devices configured by InstaCal. Subsequent calls with =GetNext returns each of the other device types in InstaCal. When you reach the end of the list, is set to an empty string.

member.name: M:MccDaq.MccService.FileRead(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Reads data from a streamer file, and returns the data in an array.
member.param: Name of the streamer file.
Index of the first point to read.
The number of points to read from the file.
An array used to store the data read from the file.
member.returns: An object that indicates the status of the operation.

item.description: Data format: The data is returned as 16 bits. The 16 bits may represent 12 bits of analog, 12-bits of analog plus 4 bits of channel, or 16-bits of analog. Use method to correctly load the data into an array.

Loading portions of files: The file may contain much more data than can fit in dataBuffer. In those cases, use totalCount and firstPoint to read a selected piece of the file into dataBuffer. Call method first to find out how many points are in the file.
